p: The underlying concern is that urban climate politics is dominated by economic interests and investment opportunities closely linked to a perpetuation of neoliberal logics. Whitehead (2013) distinguishes parallels between climate adaptation agendas and neoliberal interests, in terms of efforts to protect and build (global) capital investment and means of production. Hodson and Marvin (2012) demonstrate how economic stakeholders dominated the formulation of a low‐carbon vision for Greater Manchester, which perpetuated the focus on economic growth rather than opening up for socio‐environmental change. Ahmed, Nahiduzzaman, and Hasan (2018) argues that adaptation planning in Asian and African cities is based on neoliberal fantasies of a Singaporean development model that ignore the realities of most urban inhabitants.
